stories.text:
I imagine a game like this:

Everyone who thinks the search results for a certain query are crap posts the query here and the first two results in alphabetical order.

Then everybody comments, which result should be #1 and which should be #2. Before looking at the actual results.

What does everyone think about this idea?
stories.title: Ask HN: Should we do some blind tests, how good the Google search results are?

stories.text:
I am unable to identify an Android One phone released in the last 3 quarters and the Google site now promises only 2 years of maintenance, so 1.1 years of support if bought today.

Are there options besides Apple and Google(?) that ~always deliver maintenance at least as long as the hardware warranty?
stories.title: Ask HN: Android One Is Dead?

Show HN: A pseudo-random directory hierarchy generator written in Rust

stories.text:
Facebook, Twitter, Reddit, and video game companies like King (makers of candy crush) make their money by getting us to spend as much time as possible on their products.

They spend millions working out how best to pull you into their products, and to keep you scrolling and crushing candies once you’re in.

I believe the addictive nature of these apps is causing an existential crisis. People are no longer achieving goals aligned with their values — and, since this technology allows no time for introspection — may even not know their values.

This was certainly true for me.

So I’d love to hear what acts of resistance (or productivity hacks) you’ve engaged in to help yourself avoid these apps.
stories.title: Ask HN: How do you avoid online distractions and tech addiction?
